H0.text: The Moon's path around Earth is why its appearance changes over time when observed from Earth.

H1.text: Length of daylight is the reason the appearance of the Moon as observed from Earth changes over time.

H2.text: Gravity is the reason the appearance of the Moon as observed from Earth changes over time.

H3.text: Temperature is the factor that causes the Moon's appearance, as observed from Earth, to change over time.

A6.text: At that time the Moon is a bit ahead in its orbit with respect to its rotation about its axis, and this creates a perspective effect which makes up to eight degrees of longitude of its eastern far side visible.

A7.text: When the inclination of the Moon's orbit to the Earth's equator is at its minimum of 18°20′, the centre of the Moon's disk will be above the horizon every day from latitudes less than 70°43' (90° − 18°20' – 57' parallax) north or south.
